hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of a binary tree. Each node can have up to two children, and the relationship between nodes is hierarchical. Remember that an ancestor is any node on the path from the root to the node itself.

Think about how you can traverse the tree. Depth-first search (DFS) or breadth-first search (BFS) are common techniques for tree traversal. Which one do you think would be more suitable for this problem?
As you traverse the tree, keep track of the maximum and minimum values encountered on the path from the root to the current node. This will help you calculate the differences later.

Consider how you will define the maximum difference. You need to calculate the absolute differences between the current node's value and the maximum/minimum values encountered on the path to that node.
When you reach a leaf node, you should have enough information to calculate the difference. However, you need to ensure that you are updating the maximum difference as you traverse back up the tree.
Pay attention to the constraints given in the problem. The number of nodes can be up to 5000, so your solution should be efficient. Avoid unnecessary computations or traversals.
Think about edge cases, such as when the tree is skewed (all nodes have only one child). How would this affect your calculations of differences?
You might want to use a recursive function to handle the DFS traversal. Consider passing the current maximum and minimum values as parameters to the recursive function.

When calculating the maximum difference, ensure that you are comparing the current node's value with both the maximum and minimum values from the path. This will give you the correct absolute difference.
Finally, make sure to return the maximum difference found after completing the traversal of the entire tree. You can do this by maintaining a global variable to store the maximum difference.

questionNotes: Constraints: The number of nodes in the tree is in the range [2, 5000].
Node values are in the range [0, 100000].
Ensure to handle both maximum and minimum values when calculating differences.
A node is considered an ancestor if it is on the path from the root to the node.
